title: 106_s3125
content: The "Sustaining Access to Vital Emergency Medical Services Act of 2000" includes provisions for rural emergency medical service training and equipment assistance, a tax credit for volunteer providers, a study on rural ambulance service costs, and the elimination of inflation adjustment reductions for ambulance services. Additionally, a new section is added to the Public Health Service Act for a Rural Emergency Medical Service Training and Equipment Assistance Program. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities to improve emergency medical services in rural areas. Eligible entities include State emergency medical services offices, State departments of Transportation, State emergency medical services associations, State offices of rural health, or other entities approved by the Secretary. Applicants must submit an application with required information. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for improving emergency medical services in rural areas. Recipients must use the funds to hire or recruit personnel, retain volunteers, and train emergency medical service personnel. The grants awarded by the Secretary aim to enhance emergency medical services in rural areas by training personnel, funding specific training, utilizing technology for education, acquiring vehicles and equipment, and providing personal protective gear. The Secretary awards grants to enhance emergency medical services in rural areas by training personnel, funding specific training, educating the public on CPR and first aid, and giving preference to entities planning activities related to emergency preparedness. Grants require non-Federal contributions from the entity. The term 'emergency medical services' refers to resources used by qualified entities to provide medical care outside of a facility during emergencies, including services by licensed providers. Non-Federal contributions are required for grants to enhance rural emergency medical services, with a preference for activities related to emergency preparedness. The State-licensed emergency medical services provider can include EMTs, paramedics, nurses, physician assistants, or physicians. $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2001 through 2006 for this program, with up to 10% for administrative costs. Tax credit for volunteer emergency medical service providers is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax credit of $500 allowed for eligible volunteer emergency medical service providers listed as active on official staff roster of squad. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of emergency medical services and volunteers for tax purposes. It also mentions the Secretary's ability to require additional verification. The Secretary may require additional information for verification of eligibility for the tax credit under this section. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. Study and report on the costs of rural ambulance services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on identifying rural areas with low population densities for higher ambulance service costs. The study will compare costs between volunteer and hospital-based ambulance providers in rural areas and analyze factors contributing to additional costs in designated areas. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress by June 30, 2001, based on a study on adjusting fee schedules for ambulance services in low density rural areas. The regulation resulting from the study will take effect by January 1, 2002. The amendment eliminates the reduction in inflation adjustments for ambulance services in 2001 and 2002, increasing it by 1.0 percentage point in 2001.
